{{about|the blizzard in the eastern United States and Canada|the blizzard in the Great Plains|Schoolhouse Blizzard}} {{Infobox winter storm | name = Great Blizzard of 1888 | image location = 10 PM March 12 surface analysis of Great Blizzard of 1888.png | image name = [[surface weather analysis|Surface analysis]] of Blizzard on March 12, 1888 at 10 p.m. | stormtype = [[Extratropical cyclone]]
[[Blizzard]]
[[Winter March 11, 1888]] | date | RSI = | maximum amount = {{convert|58|in|cm|0}} | pressure = {{convert|982|kPa|inHg|abbr=on}} | total damages (USD) = $25 million (1888 dollars; equivalent to ${{Inflation|US|25|1888|r=-1}} million in {{currentyear}}) | total casualties = 400 fatalities | areas affected = [[Eastern United States]], [[Eastern Canada]] }} The '''Great Blizzard of 1888''' or '''Great Blizzard of '88''' (March 11 – March 14, 1888) was one of the most severe recorded [[blizzard]]s in the history of the United States of America. The storm, referred to as the '''Great White Hurricane''', paralyzed the [[East Coast of the United States|East Coast]] from the [[Chesapeake Bay]] to [[Maine]],{{cite web |url=http://www.nycsubway.org/articles/1888-blizzard.html |title=The Blizzard of 1888; the Impact of this Devastating Storm on New York Transit}} as well as the [[Atlantic Canada|Atlantic provinces of Canada]]. Snowfalls of {{convert|10|to|58|in|cm}} fell in parts of [[New Jersey]], [[New York (state)|New York]], [[Massachusetts]], [[Rhode Island]], and [[Connecticut]], and sustained winds of more than {{convert|45|mph|km/h|0}} produced [[snowdrift]]s in excess of {{convert|50|ft|m}}. Railroads were shut down, and people were confined to their houses for up to a week.{{cite book | last = Douglas | first = Paul | title = Restless Skies | publisher = [[Barnes & Noble|Barnes & Noble Publishing, Inc]]. | year = 2004 | pages = 12–13 | isbn = 0-7607-6113-2 }} Railway and [[Electrical telegraph|telegraph]] lines were disabled, and this provided the impetus to move these pieces of [[undergrounding|infrastructure underground]]. Emergency services were also affected. ==Storm details== [[File:Blizzard 1888 01.jpg|thumb|left|Streets in New York City as the storm hit. Many overhead wires broke and presented a hazard to city dwellers.{{cite web |title=Building the invisible city |publisher=Virtual New York |url=http://www.vny.cuny.edu/blizzard/building/building.html |accessdate=2007-05-10}}]] [[File:Brooklyn Bridge snowy.jpg|thumb|left|[[Brooklyn Bridge]] during the blizzard]] The weather preceding the blizzard was unseasonably mild with heavy rains that turned to snow as temperatures dropped rapidly. The storm began in earnest shortly after midnight on March 12 and continued unabated for a full day and a half. The [[National Weather Service]] estimated this [[Nor'easter]] dumped as much as {{convert|50|in|cm}} of snow in parts of Connecticut and Massachusetts, while parts of New Jersey and New York had up to {{convert|40|in|cm}}.{{cite web |url=http://www.crh.noaa.gov/mkx/climate/big.php |title=Biggest Snowstorms in the United States: From 1888 to Present |accessdate=2007-12-21 |format= |work=NWS Milwaukee/Sullivan, WI|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070324154647/http://www.crh.noaa.gov/mkx/climate/big.php|archivedate=24 March 2007|deadurl=yes}} Most of northern Vermont received from {{convert|20|in|cm}} to {{convert|30|in|cm}} in this storm.{{cite web |url=http://www5.ncdc.noaa.gov/climatenormals/clim60/states/Clim_VT_01.pdf |title=Climate of Vermont |accessdate=2007-12-21 |format=pdf |work=National Climatic Data Center |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080229021750/http://www5.ncdc.noaa.gov/climatenormals/clim60/states/Clim_VT_01.pdf |archivedate=2008-02-29 |df= }} Drifts were reported to average {{convert|30|–|40|ft|m}}, over the tops of houses from New York to New England, with reports of drifts covering three-story houses. The highest drift ({{convert|52|ft|m|disp=or}}) was recorded in [[Gravesend, Brooklyn|Gravesend, New York]]. It was reported that {{convert|58|in|cm}} of snow fell in [[Saratoga Springs, New York]]; {{convert|48|in|cm}} in [[Albany, New York]]; {{convert|45|in|cm}} of snow in [[New Haven, Connecticut]]; and {{convert|22|in|cm}} of snow in [[New York City]].{{cite web |url=http://www1.ncdc.noaa.gov/pub/data/blizzard/blizz.txt |title= The Big One! A Review of the March 12–14, 1993 "Storm of the Century" [With comparisons to the Blizzard of 1888] |accessdate=2007-12-21 |format= |work=National Climatic Data Center }} The storm also produced severe winds; {{convert|80|mph|km/h|0}} wind gusts were reported, although the highest official report in New York City was {{convert|40|mph|km/h|0}}, with a {{convert|54|mph|km/h|0}} gust reported at [[Block Island]]. New York's Central Park Observatory reported a minimum temperature of {{Convert|6|°F|°C}}, and a daytime average of {{Convert|9|°F|°C}} on March 13, the coldest ever for March. ==Impacts== In New York, neither rail nor road transport was possible anywhere for days,{{cite web |url=http://www.nycsubway.org/articles/1888-blizzard.html |title=The Blizzard of 1888; the Impact of this Devastating Storm on New York Transit}} and drifts across the [[New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad|New York–New Haven rail line]] at [[Westport, Connecticut]], took [[New Haven Line#History|eight days]] to clear. Transportation gridlock as a result of the storm was partially responsible for the creation of the [[Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority|first underground subway]] system in the United States, which opened nine years later in Boston.{{cite web |url=http://www.massmoments.com/moment.cfm?mid=77 |title=Blizzard shuts down Massachusetts |publisher=Massachusetts Foundation for the Humanities |quote=Perhaps the most important legacy of the Blizzard of 1888 was the Boston subway system. Alarmed by the paralysis and economic damage the storm caused, Boston decided to build a subway.}}{{cite web |url=http://www.nycsubway.org/articles/1888-blizzard.html |title=The Blizzard of 1888; the Impact of this Devastating Storm on New York Transit |quote=There is no overstating the significant impact this tragedy had on the metropolis, especially on transportation. The resulting standstill on the elevated lines resulted in the city adopting a plan to build subways.}} The [[New York Stock Exchange]] was closed for two days.{{cite web|title=NEW YORK STOCK EXCHANGE SPECIAL CLOSINGS, 1885–date |url=https://www.nyse.com/pdfs/closings.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070925210452/http://www.nyse.com/pdfs/closings.pdf |archivedate=2007-09-25 |df= }} Similarly, telegraph [[infrastructure]] was disabled, isolating [[Montreal]] and most of the large northeastern U.S. cities from [[Washington, D.C.]] to Boston for days. Following the storm, New York began placing its telegraph and telephone infrastructure underground to prevent their destruction. [[Fire station]]s were immobilized, and property loss from fire alone was estimated at $25 million (equivalent to ${{Inflation|US|25|1888|r=-1}} million in {{currentyear}}). The blizzard resulted in the founding of the [[Christman Bird and Wildlife Sanctuary]] located near [[Delanson, New York]]. From Chesapeake Bay through the [[New England]] area, more than 200 ships were either grounded or wrecked, resulting in the deaths of at least 100 seamen. More than 400 people died from the storm and the ensuing cold, including 200 in New York City alone.{{cite web |url=http://www.crh.noaa.gov/iwx/program_areas/wxhisttdy/index.php?url=Mar12 |title=On Mar 12 in weather history |accessdate=2007-12-21 |format= |work=NWS Northern Indiana Weather History }} Efforts were made to push the snow into the Atlantic Ocean. Severe flooding occurred after the storm due to melting snow, especially in the [[Brooklyn]] area, which was susceptible to flooding because of its topography. Not all areas were notably affected by the Blizzard of 1888; an article in the ''Cambridge Press'' published five days after the storm noted that the "fall of snow in this vicinity was comparatively small, and had it not been accompanied by a strong wind it would have been regarded as rather trifling in amount, the total depth, on a level, not exceeding ten inches".[http://cambridge.dlconsulting.com/cgi-bin/cambridge?a=d&d=Press18880317-01.2.16&e=-------en-20--1--txt-txIN------ "The Great Storm"] ''Cambridge Press'', Cambridge, MA, 17 March 1888. Retrieved 29 November 2014. [[Roscoe Conkling]], an influential [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] politician, died as a result of the storm. ==Pictures== File:Blizzard 1888 Grand Central NY.jpg|45th Street and [[Grand Central Terminal|Grand Central Depot]], [[Manhattan]], March 12 File:Brooklyn blizzard 1888.jpg|Park Place in [[Brooklyn]], March 14 File:Brooklyn Museum - Blizzard of March 1888, Brooklyn - Breading G. Way - overall.jpg|Brooklyn children after the blizzard File:StereoviewNewBritainCTGrandStMar131888BlizzardFWAllderige enh.jpg|[[New Britain, Connecticut]], March 13 File:Stebbins-11-Cythera.jpg|''Cythera'', lost with all aboard in the blizzard File:Bone-valley-trail.jpg|Bone Valley Trail, where a herd of cattle froze File:(King1893NYC) pg047 THE BLIZZARD OF MARCH 1888 (PHOTO BY LANGILL).jpg|14th Street, New York City, "just after the storm" (March 14) ==Literature== [[Edward Rutherfurd]]'s 2009 novel ''[[New York (novel)|New York]]'' has a dramatic section set during the blizzard.{{Cite web |url=http://www.edwardrutherfurd.com/new-york.html |title=New York |website=www.edwardrutherfurd.com |access-date=2018-03-09}} [[Richard Peck (writer)]]'s 1989 novel ''Voices After Midnight'', in which three California teenagers living in an old New York townhouse find themselves continually slipping back in time, also depicts the events of the blizzard dramatically during its climax.{{Cite web |url=https://www.publishersweekly.com/978-0-385-29779-0 |title=Children's Book Review: Voices After Midnight by Richard Peck |website=[[Publishers Weekly]] |language=en |access-date=2018-11-29}} Rosemary Simpson's novel ''What the Dead Leave Behind'' has also been set at this time.{{Cite web |url=https://www.publishersweekly.com/978-1-4967-0908-0 |title=Fiction Book Review: What the Dead Leave Behind by Rosemary Simpson |website=[[Publishers Weekly]] |language=en |access-date=2018-03-09}} John R. Maxim's novel, ''Time Out of Mind'' (1986) has flashbacks to this period and describes effects of the storm.{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1986/02/09/books/the-snows-of-yesteryear.html |title=The Snows of Yesteryear |last=Taliaferro |first=Frances |date=1986-02-09 |work=The New York Times |access-date=2018-03-09 |last2=Magazine |first2=a contributing editor of Harper's |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331 |last3=School |first3=teaches at the Brearley}} ''[[BLIZZARD! The Storm That Changed America]]'' is a 2000 Children's history book by [[Jim Murphy (author)|Jim Murphy]].{{cite web |url=https://www.worldcat.org/title/blizzard-the-storm-that-changed-america/oclc/41108574?referer=br&ht=edition |title=BLIZZARD! The Storm That Changed America |website=worldcat.org |publisher=OCLC |accessdate=2018-11-02 }} In the ''[[Doctor Who]]'' [[Big Finish Productions]] audio adventure ''[[Doctor Who: The First Doctor Adventures]]: The Great White Hurricane'', the [[TARDIS]] arrives in New York the day before the Great Blizzard, resulting in the [[First Doctor]] and [[Susan Foreman]] becoming caught up in a local gang conflict that ends with Susan and one of the gang trapped on the frozen Hudson river, while [[Ian Chesterton]] and [[Barbara Wright (Doctor Who)|Barbara Wright]] help an abused wife find and rescue her son from his alcoholic father, ending in a desperate rescue attempt when the father and son are part of a group of passengers trapped on a train that was crossing a bridge before snow forced it to stop.{{Cite web |url=http://thedoctorwhocompanion.com/2017/11/30/new-details-for-big-finishs-first-doctor-adventures/ |title=New Details for Big Finish’s First Doctor Adventures |date=2017-11-30 |website=The Doctor Who Companion |language=en-US |access-date=2018-03-09}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== * [http://www.infoplease.com/spot/blizzard1.html Borgna Brunner, "The Great White Hurricane"] Accessed April 17, 2012 * {{cite news | last = | first = | coauthors = | title = In a Blizzard's Grasp | work = | pages = | language = | publisher = The New York Times | date = March 13, 1888 | url = https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1888/03/13/106317050.pdf | accessdate = April 17, 2012 | format = PDF}} * [http://www.nycsubway.org/articles/1888-blizzard.html G. {{Infobox oil spill |spill_name = Guimaras oil spill|spill_date = 11 August 2006|location = [[Guimaras Strait]], [[Philippines]]|coordinates = {{coord|10|13|N|122|30|E|display=title,inline}}|image = Guimaras oil spill map with labels.jpg|image_size = 250px|image_caption = Map showing the extent of the Guimaras oil spill.|cause = Sinking of M/T ''Solar 1'' during storm |operator = Sunshine Maritime Development Corporation, [[Petron Corporation]]<ref>{{cite news | last = Baua | first = Niko | title = Petron, Sunshine Maritime face P200-M suit over oil spill | publisher = [[ABS-CBN]] | date = 2012-03-17 | url = http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/business/03/17/12/petron-sunshine-maritime-face-p200-m-suit-over-oil-spill | accessdate = 2013-05-24}}</ref>|casualties = 1 dead, 2 missing|volume = {{convert|500000|l}}|area = }}
The '''Guimaras oil spill''' occurred in the [[Panay Gulf]] on August 11, 2006 when the [[oil tanker]] M/T ''Solar 1'' sank off the coast of [[Guimaras]] and [[Negros (island)|Negros]] islands in the [[Philippines]], causing what is considered as the worst [[oil spill]] in the country.<ref name=bbc>{{cite web|title=Oil spill threatens Philippines|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/4795649.stm|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=15 July 2013|author=Sarah Toms|date=15 August 2006}}</ref><ref name="inq7-1">{{cite news | url = http://newsinfo.inq7.net/breakingnews/nation/view_article.php?article_id=16764| title = Arroyo forms task force to oversee oil spill cleanup| publisher = [[INQ7.net]]| date = 2006-08-23}}</ref>
==Background== {{refimprove section|date=February 2017}} The [[oil tanker]] M/T ''Solar 1'', carrying more than two million liters of [[bunker fuel]], sank during a violent storm approximately {{convert|20.5|km}} off the southern coast of [[Guimaras]] at around midnight on August 11, 2006,<ref>{{cite paper | author = Arias, de la Cruz, Guillergan & Presaldo | title = Responding to an Oil Spill Disaster: Data Management Support for the Rehabilitation of Guimaras Island, Philippines | publisher = International Society for Environmental Information Sciences | date = 2006 | url = http://www.iseis.org/EIA/pdfstart.asp?no=07024 | format = PDF | accessdate = 2013-05-24 | journal = | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20140812024022/http://www.iseis.org/EIA/pdfstart.asp?no=07024 | archive-date = 2014-08-12 | dead-url = yes | df = }}</ref> causing some {{convert|500000|l}} of oil to pour into the gulf, that traveled up through the [[Guimaras Strait]] and [[Iloilo Strait]]. [[Siphon]]ing the remaining 1.5 million liters from the sunken tanker, at a depth of more than {{convert|600|m}}, was scheduled for March 2007.
The oil spill adversely affected [[Marine sanctuary|marine sanctuaries]] and [[mangrove]] [[nature reserve|reserves]] in three out of five [[Municipalities of the Philippines|municipalities]] in Guimaras Island and reached the shores of [[Iloilo]] and [[Negros Occidental]]. The oil spill occurred in the Guimaras Strait that connects the [[Visayan Sea]] with the [[Sulu Sea]], and is considered a rich fishing ground that supplies most of the demand for the entire country. (NDCC, August 2006)
[[Haribon Foundation|Haribon]] sent two biologists to Guimaras to assess the damage and talk to the affected communities regarding their immediate needs. Haribon provided assistance particularly for the long-term rehabilitation of the area. The government evacuated the affected families who had been exposed to the toxic elements of the [[crude oil]]. According to reports gathered in the field, people contracted skin diseases associated with these elements.{{Citation needed|date=May 2013}}
==Causes== Several causes have been cited, including bad weather and [[human error]]. Allegations have been made stating that the tanker only had a capacity of 1.2 million liters, implying the possibility of overloading.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://coordination-maree-noire.eu/spip.php?article3881| title = Inquiry lists 3 factors behind Solar 1 sinking| publisher = The Manila Times| date = 2006-09-15}}</ref> Other investigations have claimed that the ship's Captain was not qualified to sail the vessel.{{Citation needed|date=May 2013}}
==Effects== [[File:Oil Spill 2 (Nueva Valencia, Guimaras).jpg|250px|thumbnail|left|The Taklong Island National Marine Reserve was severely damaged. This bird was rescued in one of the mangroves being cleaned up.]] The spill damaged [[Taklong Island National Marine Reserve]], a marine sanctuary for feeding and breeding ground for fish and other species.<ref name=bbc/> The oil slick also posed a threat to the [[Portunus pelagicus|blue crab]] industry in the municipality of [[Enrique B. Magalona, Negros Occidental|Enrique B. Magalona]] in [[Negros Occidental]].<ref>{{cite news| url = http://www.sunstar.com.ph/static/bac/2006/08/23/news/slick.to.ruin.blue.crabs.habitat.in.eb.magalona.html| title = Slick to ruin blue crabs habitat in EB Magalona| publisher = Sun.Star Bacolod| date = 2006-08-23| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060829144205/http://www.sunstar.com.ph/static/bac/2006/08/23/news/slick.to.ruin.blue.crabs.habitat.in.eb.magalona.html| archivedate = 2006-08-29| df = }}</ref>
Dr. Jose Ingles, eco-region coordinator of the [[World Wide Fund for Nature]] in the Philippines, Indonesia and Malaysia, said that the damage may be felt by at least two generations. He warned that the disaster may have damaged the reefs and mangroves, scarring the ecosystem and causing seafood yields to significantly decrease. According to him, the worst hit would be the shorelines, the coasts and the swamplands with mangroves. This will greatly impact the livelihood of the fishermen, mostly living in poor conditions.<ref name="inq7">{{cite news | url = http://newsinfo.inq7.net/inquirerheadlines/nation/view_article.php?article_id=16966| title = ‘Sensitive habitats can be smothered by oil’ | publisher = INQ7.net| date = 2006-08-24}}</ref>
In the south-southeast of the spill site is located the [[Sulu Sea]], a deep-water area frequented by commercially valued fish such as [[Indo-Pacific blue marlin|blue marlin]] and the [[yellowfin tuna]], prized by the towns of southern Negros Occidental province as an important source of income for the communities. The oil slick may damage this thriving local industry.{{Citation needed|date=May 2013}}
On August 22, 2006, the [[Philippine Coast Guard]] stated that the spill has affected 20 communities in 4 municipalities in Guimaras. It also threatened 27 communities in [[Iloilo province]] and 17 others in [[Negros Occidental]].<ref name="sunstar-1">{{cite news| url = http://www.sunstar.com.ph/static/bac/2006/08/23/news/governor.says.no.to.oil.sludge.disposal.in.guimaras.html| title = Governor says no to oil sludge disposal in Guimaras| publisher = Sun.Star Bacolod| date = 2006-08-23| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070717134931/http://www.sunstar.com.ph/static/bac/2006/08/23/news/governor.says.no.to.oil.sludge.disposal.in.guimaras.html| archivedate = 2007-07-17| df = }}</ref>
==Casualties== A villager from Barangay Lapaz, [[Nueva Valencia, Guimaras]], became the first casualty directly affected by the spill. He died after inhaling the fumes of the oil sludge caused him to contract cardio-respiratory disease.<ref name="sunstar-1" /> Two sailors from the ship were also reported missing.
==Response== Due to the extent of the disaster, the cleanup was expected to reach three years.<ref name=bbc/>
===Local response=== [[File:Oil Spill (Nueva Valencia, Guimaras).jpg|thumb|Cleanup in Barangay La Paz, [[Nueva Valencia, Guimaras]]]] On August 19, the Philippine government has asked the governments of [[Indonesia]], [[Japan]] and the [[United States]] to help assist with the cleanup.<ref name="inq7.net">{{cite news | url = http://newsinfo.inq7.net/inquirerheadlines/nation/view_article.php?article_id=16179| title = RP sends SOS on oil spill US, Japan, Indonesia help sought | publisher = INQ7.net| date = 2006-08-20}}</ref>
President [[Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo]] created Task Force Guimaras on August 22 in order to oversee both the cleanup of the oil spill and the retrieval of the 1.5 million liters of [[fuel oil]] still remaining inside the tanker. The government also ordered the creation of the Special Board of Marine Inquiry to determine who and what caused the spill.<ref name="inq7-1" />
[[Guimaras province|Guimaras]] Governor JC Rahman Nava has objected to the proposal of disposing the oil wastes within the province.<ref name="sunstar-1" />
Clemente Cancio, President of Sunshine Maritime Development Corporation (SMDC), the company which owns M/T Solar I, said that their foreign insurer is willing to pay the cost of damage brought about by the oil spill.<ref name="sunstar-1" />
President Gloria Arroyo ordered a full investigation into the country's worst oil spill that devastated marine ecosystems in the central Philippines. Arroyo also ordered the Justice Department to join a special task force heading an investigation and cleanup on the island of Guimaras, where some {{convert|300|km|mi|sp=us}} of coastline, including stretches of pristine beaches, had been affected by the oil slick from the sunken tanker. "We shall do everything in our power to right the wrongs caused by this unfortunate incident," Arroyo said after visiting the island, adding that she was deeply pained by the disaster that she declared a "national calamity".<ref name="PhilStar report on Guimaras oil spill">{{cite news | url = http://www.philstar.com/philstar/NEWS_FLASH082620061737_12.htm | title = Arroyo vows to get to bottom of oil spill | publisher = PhilStar | date = 2006-08-26 }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
===International response=== On August 17, [[United Kingdom|British]] oil experts, sent by SMDC's foreign insurer, arrived in Guimaras to assess the situation. SMDC stated that the experts will check the extent of the oil pollution. The Britons conducted an aerial survey over [[Guimaras Island]] and made recommendations based on their findings.<ref name="GlobalNation">{{cite news | url = http://globalnation.inq7.net/news/news/view_article.php?article_id=15982| title = British experts to help with oil spill clean-up| publisher = INQ7.net| date = 2006-08-18}}</ref><ref name="YahooBritishOil">{{cite news | url = https://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20060818/sc_afp/philippinesenvironmentshippingoil_060818061700| title = British experts to help with oil spill clean-up| publisher = YahooNews| date = 2006-08-18}}</ref>
A four-man team from the [[U.S. Coast Guard]] arrived on August 23 to assist in determining the exact location of the tanker.<ref name="sunstar-1" />
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Chembox | Watchedfields = changed | ImageFile = Helium-hydride-cation-3D-SF.png | ImageFile_Ref = {{chemboximage|correct|??}} | ImageSize = 121 | ImageName = Spacefill model of the helium hydride ion | ImageFile2 = Helium-hydride-cation-3D-balls.png | ImageFile2_Ref = {{chemboximage|correct|??}} | ImageSize2 = 121 | ImageName2 = Ball and stick model of the helium hydride ion | SystematicName = Hydridohelium(1+)<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.ebi.ac.uk/chebi/searchId.do?chebiId=33688|title = hydridohelium(1+) (CHEBI:33688)|work = Chemical Entities of Biological Interest (ChEBI)|location = UK|publisher = European Bioinformatics Institute}}</ref> | Section1 = {{Chembox Identifiers | ChemSpiderID = 21106447 | ChemSpiderID_Ref = {{chemspidercite|correct|chemspider}} | ChEBI = 33688 | Gmelin = 2 | SMILES = [HeH+] | StdInChI = 1S/HHe/h1H/q+1 | StdInChI_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChIKey = HSFAAVLNFOAYQX-UHFFFAOYSA-N | StdInChIKey_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} }} | Section2 = {{Chembox Properties | Formula = {{Chem|HeH|+}} | He=1|H=1 | ConjugateBase = [[Helium]] }} }}
The '''hydrohelium(1+)''' cation, HeH<sup>+</sup>, also known as the '''helium hydride ion''' or '''helium-hydride molecular ion''', is a [[electric charge|positively charged]] [[ion (chemistry)|ion]] formed by the reaction of a [[proton]] with a [[helium]] [[atom]] in the [[gas phase]], first produced in the laboratory in 1925. It is [[isoelectronic]] with molecular [[hydrogen]].<ref>{{cite journal|author1=T. R. Hogness |author2=E. G. Lunn |title = The Ionization of Hydrogen by Electron Impact as Interpreted by Positive Ray Analysis|journal = [[Physical Review]]|year = 1925|volume = 26|issue = 1|pages = 44–55|doi = 10.1103/PhysRev.26.44|bibcode=1925PhRv...26...44H}}</ref> It is the strongest known acid, with a [[proton affinity]] of 177.8 kJ/mol.<ref name="Epa">{{cite journal|doi = 10.1063/1.555719|author = Lias, S. G.; Liebman, J. F.; Levin, R. D.|year = 1984|title = Evaluated Gas Phase Basicities and Proton Affinities of Molecules; Heats of Formation of Protonated Molecules|journal =Journal of Physical and Chemical Reference Data|volume = 13|issue = 3|pages = 695|bibcode = 1984JPCRD..13..695L |last2 = Liebman|last3 = Levin}}</ref> It has been suggested that HeH<sup>+</sup> should occur naturally in the [[interstellar medium]], but it has not yet been detected.<ref>{{cite journal|author = J. Fernandez; F. Martin|title = Photoionization of the HeH<sup>+</sup> molecular ion|journal = J. Phys. B: At. Mol. Opt. Phys.|year = 2007|volume = 40|issue = 12 |pages = 2471–2480|doi = 10.1088/0953-4075/40/12/020|bibcode = 2007JPhB...40.2471F |last2 = Martín}}</ref> It is the simplest [[heteronuclear]] ion, and is comparable with the [[hydrogen molecular ion]], {{chem|H|2|+}}. Unlike {{chem|H|2|+}}, however, it has a permanent [[Molecular dipole moment|dipole moment]], which makes its spectroscopic characterization easier.<ref>{{cite journal|doi = 10.1006/jmsp.1998.7740|title = Experimental Born–Oppenheimer Potential for the X<sub>1</sub>Σ<sup>+</sup> Ground State of HeH<sup>+</sup>: Comparison with the Ab Initio Potential|year = 1999|author = Coxon, J|journal = Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy|volume = 193|pages = 306–318|pmid = 9920707|last2 = Hajigeorgiou|first2 = PG|issue = 2|bibcode = 1999JMoSp.193..306C }}</ref> The calculated dipole moment of HeH<sup>+</sup> is 2.26 or 2.84.<ref>{{Cite web|url=ned.unifenas.br/amdias/wp-admin/apostilas/hf1s.pdf|title=Dipole Moment Calculation to Small Diatomic Molecules: Implementation on a Two-Electron Self-Consistent-Field ab initio Program|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref>
==Properties==
HHe<sup>+</sup> cannot be prepared in a [[condensed phase]], as it would [[protonate]] any anion, molecule or atom with which it were associated. However it is possible to estimate a ''hypothetical'' aqueous acidity using [[Hess's law]]:
:{| |- | HHe<sup>+</sup>(''g'') | → | H<sup>+</sup>(''g'') | + He(''g'') | align=right|+178 kJ/mol | <ref name="Epa"/> |- | HHe<sup>+</sup>(''aq'') | → | HHe<sup>+</sup>(''g'') |   | align=right|+973 kJ/mol | <ref>Estimated to be the same as for Li<sup>+</sup>(''aq'') → Li<sup>+</sup>(''g'').</ref> |- | H<sup>+</sup>(''g'') | → | H<sup>+</sup>(''aq'') |   | align=right|−1530 kJ/mol |   |- style="border-bottom:2px solid black" | He(''g'') | → | He(''aq'') |   | align=right|+19 kJ/mol | <ref name="EstSol">Estimated from solubility data.</ref> |- | '''HHe<sup>+</sup>(''aq'')''' | '''→''' | '''H<sup>+</sup>(''aq'')''' | '''+ He(''aq'')''' | align=right|'''−360 kJ/mol''' |   |- |}
A [[Thermodynamic free energy|free energy]] change of dissociation of −360 kJ/mol is equivalent to a [[Acid dissociation constant|p''K''<sub>a</sub>]] of −63.
The length of the [[covalent bond]] in HeH<sup>+</sup> is 0.772 [[Ångstrom|Å]].<ref name="Coyne">{{Cite journal| last = Coyne| first = John P.|author2=Ball, David W.| title = Alpha particle chemistry. On the formation of stable complexes between He<sup>2+</sup> and other simple species: implications for atmospheric and interstellar chemistry| journal = Journal of Molecular Modeling| volume = 15 | issue = 1| pages = 35–40|year = 2009| doi = 10.1007/s00894-008-0371-3| pmid = 18936986}}</ref>
Other helium hydride ions are known or have been studied theoretically. {{chem|HeH|2|+}}, which has been observed using microwave spectroscopy,<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Alan Carrington |author2=David I. Gammie |author3=Andrew M. Shaw |author4=Susie M. Taylor |author5=Jeremy M. Hutson |title = Observation of a microwave spectrum of the long-range He⋯{{chem|H|2|+}} complex|journal = Chemical Physics Letters|year = 1996|volume = 260|issue = 3–4|pages = 395–405|doi = 10.1016/0009-2614(96)00860-3|bibcode = 1996CPL...260..395C }}</ref> has a calculated binding energy of 25.1 kJ/mol, while {{chem|HeH|3|+}} has a calculated binding energy of 0.42 kJ/mol.<ref>F. Pauzat and Y. Ellinger [http://asilomar.caltech.edu/abstracts_processed/Pauzat_2z6IeIOR.pdf Where do noble gases hide in space?] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070202203834/http://asilomar.caltech.edu/abstracts_processed/Pauzat_2z6IeIOR.pdf |date=2007-02-02 }}, Astrochemistry: Recent Successes and Current Challenges, Poster Book IAU Symposium No. 231, 2005 A. J. Markwick-Kemper (ed.)</ref>
The dihelium hydride cation is formed by the reaction of [[dihelium]] cation with molecular hydrogen: :{{chem|He|2|+}} + H<sub>2</sub> → He<sub>2</sub>H<sup>+</sup> + H<sup>•</sup>. He<sub>2</sub>H<sup>+</sup> is a linear ion with hydrogen in the centre.<ref name=Gran004>{{cite journal|last1=Grandinetti|first1=Felice|title=Helium chemistry: a survey of the role of the ionic species|journal=International Journal of Mass Spectrometry|date=October 2004|volume=237|issue=2-3|pages=243–267|doi=10.1016/j.ijms.2004.07.012|bibcode=2004IJMSp.237..243G}}</ref>
==Reactions== The helium hydride cation reacts with most substances. It has been shown to add a proton to [[Oxygen|O<sub>2</sub>]], [[Ammonia|NH<sub>3</sub>]], [[Sulfur dioxide|SO<sub>2</sub>]], [[Water|H<sub>2</sub>O]], and [[Carbon dioxide|CO<sub>2</sub>]], giving O<sub>2</sub>H<sup>+</sup>, [[Ammonium|{{chem|NH|4|+}}]], {{chem|HSO|2|+}}, [[Hydronium|H<sub>3</sub>O<sup>+</sup>]], and {{chem|HCO|2|+}}.<ref name=Gran004/> Other molecules such as [[nitric oxide]], [[nitrogen dioxide]], [[nitrous oxide]], [[hydrogen sulfide]], [[methane]], [[acetylene]], [[ethylene]], [[ethane]], [[methanol]] and [[acetonitrile]] react but break up due to the large amount of energy produced.<ref name=Gran004/> One technique used to study reactions between organic substances and HeH<sup>+</sup> is to make a tritium derivative of the organic compound. Decay of tritium to <sup>3</sup>He<sup>+</sup> followed by its extraction of a hydrogen atom yields <sup>3</sup>HeH<sup>+</sup> which is then surrounded by the organic material and will in turn react.<ref name=Gran004/>
Extra helium atoms can attach to HeH<sup>+</sup> to form larger clusters such as He<sub>2</sub>H<sup>+</sup>, He<sub>3</sub>H<sup>+</sup>, He<sub>4</sub>H<sup>+</sup>, He<sub>5</sub>H<sup>+</sup> and He<sub>6</sub>H<sup>+</sup> which is particularly stable.<ref name=Grand004>{{cite journal|last1=Grandinetti|first1=Felice|title=Helium chemistry: a survey of the role of the ionic species|journal=International Journal of Mass Spectrometry|date=October 2004|volume=237|issue=2–3|pages=243–267|doi=10.1016/j.ijms.2004.07.012|bibcode=2004IJMSp.237..243G}}</ref>
==Natural occurrence== The helium hydride ion is formed during the decay of [[tritium]] in the molecule HT or tritium molecule T<sub>2</sub>. Although excited by the recoil from the beta decay, the molecule remains bound together.<ref>F Mannone: ''Safety in Tritium Handling Technology'' Springer 1993, p 92</ref>
HeH<sup>+</sup> is thought to exist in the [[interstellar medium]], although it has not yet been unambiguously detected.<ref name="EngelEtAl">{{Cite journal| last = Engel| first = Elodie A.| authorlink = |author2=Doss, Natasha |author3=Harris, Gregory J. |author4=Tennyson, Jonathan| title = Calculated spectra for HeH<sup>+</sup> and its effect on the opacity of cool metal-poor stars| journal = Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society| volume = 357| issue = 2| pages = 471–477| year =2005| doi = 10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.08611.x| bibcode=2005MNRAS.357..471E|arxiv = astro-ph/0411267 }}</ref> It is believed to be the first compound to have formed in the universe,<ref name="EngelEtAl"/> and is of fundamental importance in understanding the chemistry of the early universe.<ref name="LiuEtAl">{{Cite journal | title = An ISO Long Wavelength Spectrometer detection of CH in NGC 7027 and an HeH<sup>+</sup> upper limit | journal = Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society | volume = 290 | issue = 4| pages = L71–L75| year = 1997| bibcode = 1997MNRAS.290L..71L | last1 = Liu | first1 = X.-W. | last2 = Barlow | first2= M.J. | last3 = Dalgarno| first3= A. | last4 = Tennyson | first4= J. | last5 = Lim | first5= T. | last6 = Swinyard | first6= B.M. | last7 = Cernicharo | first7= J. | last8 = Cox | first8 = P. | last9 = Baluteau | first9= J.-P. | last10 = Pequignot | first10 = D. | last11= Nguyen | first11 = Q.R. | last12 = Emery | first12= R.J. | last13= Clegg | first13= P.E. | doi=10.1093/mnras/290.4.l71}}</ref> This is because hydrogen and helium were almost the only types of atoms formed in [[Big Bang nucleosynthesis]]. Stars formed from the primordial material should contain HeH<sup>+</sup>, which could influence their formation and subsequent evolution. In particular, its strong [[Molecular dipole moment|dipole moment]] makes it relevant to the opacity of [[Metallicity#Population III stars|zero-metallicity stars]].<ref name="EngelEtAl"/> HeH<sup>+</sup> is also thought to be an important constituent of the atmospheres of helium-rich white dwarfs, where it increases the opacity of the gas and causes the star to cool more slowly.<ref name="HarrisEtAl">{{Cite journal| last = Harris| first = G.J. |author2=Lynas-Gray, A.E. |author3=Miller, S. |author4=Tennyson, J. | title = The Role of HeH<sup>+</sup> in Cool Helium-rich White Dwarfs| journal = [[The Astrophysical Journal]]|volume = 617| issue = 2| pages = L143–L146|year = 2004|doi = 10.1086/427391| bibcode=2004ApJ...617L.143H|arxiv = astro-ph/0411331 }}</ref>
Several locations have been suggested as possible places HeH<sup>+</sup> might be detected. These include cool [[helium star]]s,<ref name="EngelEtAl"/> [[H II region]]s,<ref name="RobergeDelgarno">{{Cite journal| last = Roberge| first = W.|author2=Delgarno, A.| title = The formation and destruction of HeH<sup>+</sup> in astrophysical plasmas| journal = [[The Astrophysical Journal]]| volume = 255| pages = 489–496| year = 1982| doi = 10.1086/159849| bibcode=1982ApJ...255..489R}}</ref> and dense [[planetary nebula]]e<ref name = "RobergeDelgarno"/> (in particular [[NGC 7027]]).<ref name = "LiuEtAl"/> Detecting HeH<sup>+</sup> spectroscopically is complicated by the fact that one of its most prominent spectral lines, at 149.14 [[micrometer|μm]], coincides with a doublet of spectral lines belonging to the [[methylidyne radical]] '''⫶'''CH.<ref name="EngelEtAl"/>
HeH<sup>+</sup> could be formed in the cooling gas behind dissociative shocks in dense interstellar clouds, such as the shocks caused by [[stellar wind]]s, [[supernova]]e and outflowing material from young stars. If the speed of the shock is greater than about 90 km/s, quantities large enough to detect might be formed. If detected, the emissions from HeH<sup>+</sup> would then be useful tracers of the shock.<ref name="NeufeldDelgarno">{{Cite journal| last = Neufeld| first = David A.|author2=Dalgarno, A.| title = Fast molecular shocks. I – Reformation of molecules behind a dissociative shock| journal = [[Astrophysical Journal]]| volume = 340| pages = 869–893|year = 1989|doi = 10.1086/167441| bibcode=1989ApJ...340..869N}}</ref>
==Neutral molecule== Unlike the helium hydride ion, the neutral helium hydride ''molecule'' is not stable in the ground state. However, it does exist in an excited state as an [[excimer]], and its spectrum was first observed in the mid 1980s.<ref>{{cite journal|title = Observation of Fluorescence of the HeH Molecule|author1=Thomas Möller |author2=Michael Beland |author3=Georg Zimmerer |journal = Phys. Rev. Lett.|volume = 55|pages = 2145–2148|year = 1985|doi = 10.1103/PhysRevLett.55.2145|pmid = 10032060|issue = 20|bibcode=1985PhRvL..55.2145M}}</ref><ref>[http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/physics/laureates/2001/ketterle-autobio.html Wolfgang Ketterle], The Nobel Prize in Physics 2001</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title = Emission spectra of bound helium hydride |author1=W. Ketterle |author2=H. Figger |author3=H. Walther |journal = Phys. Rev. Lett.|volume = 55|pages = 2941–2944|year = 1985|doi = 10.1103/PhysRevLett.55.2941|pmid = 10032281|issue = 27|bibcode=1985PhRvL..55.2941K}}</ref>

{{Speciesbox | name = Cranberry hibiscus | image = Haceto.jpg | genus = Hibiscus | species = acetosella | authority = [[Welw.]] ex [[William Philip Hiern|Hiern.]] }}
'''''Hibiscus acetosella''''', the '''cranberry hibiscus''' or '''African rosemallow''', is an [[flowering plant]] of the genus ''[[Hibiscus]]'' or rosemallow. The word ''acetosella'' is of Latin origin and is derived from an old name for sorrel (Oxalis) which comes from the sour taste experienced when eating the young leaves of the plant.<ref name="numberfive">Klingaman, Gerald (23 September 2011). [http://www.arhomeandgarden.org/plantoftheweek/articles/hibiscus_redleafed_9-23-11.htm "Plant of the Week: Red-Leafed Hibiscus, Latin: Hibiscus acetosella."] Division of Agriculture, University of Arkansas.</ref> ''Hibiscus acetosella'' is also known colloquially as '''false roselle''', '''maroon mallow''', '''red leaved hibiscus''', and '''red shield hibiscus'''.<ref name="Grubben2004"/> It is one of the approximately 200–300 species that are seen in sub-tropic and tropic regions.<ref name="Grubben2004"/> This ornamental is usually found in abandoned fields or open areas, marshes, and forest clearings.<ref name="Grubben2004">{{cite book|author=Grubben, Gerardus J. H. |title=Vegetables|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6jrlyOPfr24C&pg=PA312|year=2004|publisher=PROTA|isbn=978-90-5782-147-9|pages=312–313}}</ref> Cranberry hibiscus is a member of a perennial group known as hardy hibiscus.<ref name="numbertwo"/> In contrast to the tropical hibiscus, hardy hibiscus can tolerate colder conditions, are more vigorous, longer lasting, and have larger flowers.<ref name="numbertwo">Knox, Gary W. [http://edis.ifas.ufl.edu/ep245 "Hardy Hibiscus for Florida Landscapes"]. University of Florida Extension. Retrieved 2013-06-02</ref> In colder climates, ''Hibiscus acetosella'' is easily an annual, but is often regarded as a perennial to zone 8–11. During one season, the plant can grow {{convert|90|–|170|cm|ft|abbr=on}} tall and {{convert|75|cm|in|abbr=on}} wide as a shrub-subshrub.<ref name="Numberone">Mahr, Susan (21 April 2008). [http://wimastergardener.org/?q=HIbiscus_acetosella "Hibiscus Acetosella."] Wisconsin Master Gardener. University of Wisconsin.</ref>
==Characteristics==
The foliage of cranberry hibiscus is similar to that of the Japanese maple. It has dicot leaves which vary in shape from 3-5-lobed to un-lobed or undivided in the upper leaves of the plant and are generally the size of a small child's hand, about 10×10 cm.<ref name="Grubben2004"/><ref name="numberthree">[http://plants.usda.gov/java/profile?symbol=HIAC3 "PLANTS Profile: ''Hibiscus acetosella'' Welw. ex Hiern. African rosemallow"]. United States Department of Agriculture.</ref> They tend to be alternate, simple, and deeply cut with crenate or jagged edges.<ref name="numberfive"/> Leaf color is observed as a dark maroon to a patchy red/green appearance. Stipules are linear, measured approximately 1.5 cm in length.<ref name="Grubben2004"/> Both stems and petioles (3–11 cm in length) are smooth or generally free from hair.<ref name="Grubben2004"/> Acetosella is further divided into a section called Furcaria, which is a group of approximately 100 species that have non-fleshy calyx or sepals.<ref name="Grubben2004"/> The sepals contain 10 veins, 5 of which run to the apices of the segments; the other 5 run to the sinuses.<ref name="Grubben2004"/> Stems tend to be variegated.<ref name="Numberone"/> Flowers are solitary and sit atop a 1 cm long pedicel. They vary in color and are most often the dark maroon that is characteristic of the foliage with darker vein-like markings. Flowers are rarely yellow in color and are about 5 cm {2 inches} deep. Each flower contains numerous stamens at about 2 cm in length.<ref name="Grubben2004"/> The cranberry hibiscus is bisexual and is thought to be self-pollinating. It produces seeds that are reniform and dark brown with dimensions of 3×2.5 mm.<ref name="Grubben2004"/>
== Genetics ==
''Hibiscus acetosella'' is an allotetraploid [2n = 4x = 72] with a genome composition of AABB.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Contreras, Ryan N., Ruter, John M. and Hanna, Wayne W. |journal=Journal of the American Society for Horticultural Science|title=An Oryzalin-induced Autoallooctoploid of ''Hibiscus Acetosella'' 'Panama Red' |url=http://journal.ashspublications.org/content/134/5/553.abstract|volume= 134 |issue= 5 |pages=553–559}}</ref> It is often used to transfer genetic resistance to root-knot nematodes with compatible Hibiscus species. Cranberry hibiscus is often grown after tomatoes and potatoes and related species of which are not resistant to nematodes<ref name="Grubben2004"/>
== Origin ==
''Hibiscus acetosella'' is thought to have come about via hybridization between ''Hibiscus asper Hook.f.'' and ''Hibiscus surattensis L.'' secondary to their cultivation.<ref name="Grubben2004"/> It was first recognized in 1896 by French botanists as a distinct plant and given the name it currently has. The plant was probably first found growing around African villages in the southern DR Congo-Angola-Zambia region. The crop was brought to Brazil and South-East Asia where it was most likely used as sustenance for slaves.<ref name="Grubben2004"/> It is now considered more popular in Brazil than its original location in Africa, where it is now regularly cultivated and eaten as a spinach-like green.
== Living conditions ==
Cranberry hibiscus is cultivated in medium altitudes in areas of high rainfall although it does do fairly well in droughts.<ref name="Grubben2004"/> It requires moist soil with good drainage and a range of partial shade to full sun exposure.<ref name="Grubben2004"/> The plant does well in slightly acidic conditions with a soil pH between 6.1 and 6.5.<ref name="numberfour">[http://edibleplantproject.org/cranberryhibiscus/ "Cranberry Hibiscus (Hibiscus acetosella, False roselle, African rosemallow)."] Edibleplantproject.org.</ref> Cranberry hibiscus tends to flower late in season when days are shorter. Flowers open for a few hours during the late fall to early winter at midday.<ref name="Numberone"/> Although the plant itself remains in bloom for a few weeks, once open, a flower remains so for just one day. Plants typically succumb to cold weather in the Midwest prior to flowers appearing
== Growing at home ==
Seeds germinate easily within 3–4 days in a container but tend to grow rapidly. Light is not required for germination. Cranberry hibiscus propagates well with cuttings, which will take root in soil or water.<ref name="Numberone"/> The plant can be maintained in an oval form by pinching or cutting it back during the summer. Otherwise, it will have one dominant stem.<ref name="numberfive"/>
== Edible properties ==
Cranberry hibiscus is mostly known for its slightly sour or pleasantly tart young leaves which are commonly used as a vegetable, either raw or cooked. In South America, the leaves are used sparingly in salads and stir-fries. Leaves are eaten in small quantities due to acid content and because they are mucilaginous. Cranberry hibiscus leaves also contribute to the décor of various dishes since they retain their color after being cooked.<ref name="numberfour"/>
Flowers are used to make teas or other drinks where they contribute color rather than taste. In Central America the flowers are combined with ice, sugar, lemon, or lime juice and water to make a purple lemonade.<ref name="Grubben2004"/><ref name="numberfour"/>
The root is edible however thought of as fibrous and distasteful.<ref name="Grubben2004"/> Contrary to similar species such as the ''[[Hibiscus sabdariffa]]'', the calyx or sepals of ''Hibiscus acetosella'' is non-fleshy and not eaten.<ref name="numberfour"/> In Angola a tea made from the leaves of cranberry hibiscus are used as a post-fever tonic and to treat anemia.<ref name="Grubben2004"/> The plant is also utilized to treat myalgias by crushing leaves into cold water to bathe children.<ref name="Grubben2004"/> The plant is thought to contain [[polyphenols]], a compound that may combat inflammation and is commonly used to treat inflammatory diseases.<ref name ="number 6">{{cite journal|vauthors=Tsumbu CN, Deby-Dupont G, Tits M, Angenot L, Frederich M, Kohnen S, Mouithys-Mickalad A, Serteyn D, Franck T |title=Polyphenol Content and Modulatory Activities of Some Tropical Dietary Plant Extracts on the Oxidant Activities of Neutrophils and Myeloperoxidase|journal= International Journal of Molecular Sciences|year= 2012|volume= 13|issue=1|pages=628–650|doi=10.3390/ijms13010628|pmid=22312276|pmc=3269710}}</ref>
==Gallery== <gallery> File:Cranberry hibiscus leaves.jpg|''H. acetosella'' leaves File:Cranberry hibiscus budding.jpg|''H. acetosella'' budding File:Cranberry hibiscus flower.jpg|''H. acetosella'' flower File:Cranberry hibiscus full bloom.jpg|''H. acetosella'' full bloom File:Cranberry hibiscus close up.jpg|''H. acetosella'' close up File:2013.11.01.112231 Cranberry hibiscus - Hibiscus acetosella - Hilo Hawaii.jpg|Photographed in Hilo, Hawaii </gallery>

{{notability|Web|date=March 2013}} '''Home Energy Saver''' is a set of on–line resources developed by the [[U.S. Department of Energy]] at the [[Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory]] intended to help consumers and professional energy analysts, analyze, reduce, and manage home energy use.<ref name="Tyghe">{{cite web|url=http://discovermagazine.com/2008/may/31-would-al-gore-call-you-naughty-or-nice|title=Would Al Gore Call You Naughty or Nice?|last=Trimble|first=Tyghe|date=March 31, 2008|publisher=Kalmbach Publishing Co.|accessdate=2 October 2010}}</ref>
The Home Energy Saver energy assessment tool allows consumers to conduct a do-it-yourself home [[energy audit]] and provides specific recommendations to help lower household [[Domestic energy consumption|energy consumption]] and utility costs. By entering a zip code, users get estimates for typical and efficient homes in their area.<ref>{{cite web|last=Janeway |first=Kimberly |title=This Audit Might Actually Save You Money |url=http://blogs.consumerreports.org/home/2008/01/home-energy-use.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080113053028/http://blogs.consumerreports.org/home/2008/01/home-energy-use.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=13 January 2008 |publisher=Consumer Reports |accessdate=10 January 2008 }}</ref> The estimates break down energy consumption by "end use". End uses reported by Home Energy Saver include: [[heating]], [[Air conditioning|cooling]], [[water heating]], [[major appliances]], [[small appliances]], and [[lighting]].
The more details a user enters, (e.g., [[Building insulation|insulation]] levels, [[Roofing material|roofing]], age of major equipment, how systems are used) the more customized the assessment results and [[Efficient energy use|energy efficiency]] recommendations become. The tailored reports allows consumers to drill into estimated cost of improvements, anticipated [[Payback period|payback]] time, projected utility bill savings, and how much energy use and [[green house gas]] production will be reduced. Consumers can vary the [[Efficient energy use|energy efficiency]] assumptions and the upgrade costs, (e.g., replacing the default values with actual estimates from contractors) and recalculate the [[Payback period|payback]] times and other details.
The Home Energy Saver website includes a section called LEARN which offers tips about energy savings, an explanation of the house-as-system energy efficiency approach, and other information to help people understand how energy is used in a home.
When launched in 1994, Home Energy Saver was the first and only online home energy calculator. Thereafter, 6 million people have used it to analyze their home energy use. Nearly 1 million people visit the site each year. In 2009, a second version of the tool, Home Energy Saver Professional, was launched. This advanced version provides a low cost, interactive energy simulation/assessments tool for [[contractors]], building professionals, [[weatherization]] professionals, and building designers.
== The Home Energy Simulation Model == The Home Energy Saver is built on DOE-2, a computer program for building heating and cooling energy analysis and design.<ref>{{cite web|title=Calculating Energy Savings |url=http://www.rdmag.com/Awards/Rd-100-Awards/2010/08/Calculating-Energy-Savings/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101203034544/http://www.rdmag.com/Awards/Rd-100-Awards/2010/08/Calculating-Energy-Savings/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=3 December 2010 |publisher=R&D |accessdate=12 August 2010 }}</ref> DOE-2 performs a thermal load simulation that accounts for heating and cooling equipment and thermal distribution efficiencies, infiltration, and thermostat management.<ref>Raad. Z. Homod, K. S. M. Sahari, H. A.F. Almurib, F. H. Nagi, Double cooling coil model for non-linear HVAC system using RLF method, Energy and Buildings, Volume 43 (2011) 2043–2054</ref> User-entered zip codes are mapped to one of about 300 unique "weather tapes" that impose a year's worth of local weather conditions on the home to determine heating and cooling needs.
Home Energy Saver extends DOE-2 in a number of ways to improve the simulation model.<ref>Raad Z. Homod, K.S.M. Sahari, H.A.F. Mohamed, F. Nagi, Modeling of heat and moisture transfer in building using RLF method, conference on research and development, IEEE, (2010) 287 – 292</ref> For example, when users enter their actual electricity tariffs, the predictive power of the model improves. Other methods are used to calculate the energy used by appliances, water heating, and lighting.
The [[public domain]] HES calculation methods and underlying data are clearly documented on the website. Other web-based tool developers are welcome to use this information at no cost, providing that the source is properly credited.
== Energy Saving Recommendations == The Home Energy Saver enables users to quantify the benefits of improving the energy efficiency and comfort of homes in the following ways:<ref>{{cite web|last=Orman|first=Suzie|title=The Cheapest Way to Go Green|url=http://www.oprah.com/money/Suze-Ormans-Guide-to-Making-Low-Cost-Eco-Upgrades/print/1|publisher=Oprah.com|accessdate=25 March 2010}}</ref>
* No Cost Changes – No cost changes are modifications to the way energy is used, like lowering the [[hot water heater]] temperature, unplugging the second [[refrigerator]] that is running to cool just a few things, doing laundry with cool or cold water instead of hot, or programming the [[thermostat]] a bit lower. These changes don't cost anything, but they can save a substantial amount of energy over time. * Low Cost Changes – Low cost changes include actions like changing out [[incandescent light bulbs]] for [[compact fluorescent lamps]] (CFLs) or [[LED|LED bulbs]], wrapping a hot water heater in an insulating blanket, or [[weatherization|weatherizing]] a home by caulking or adding weather stripping. Low cost changes are typically [[Do-It-Yourself]] tasks that can improve the energy efficiency of a home dramatically. * Deep Home Energy Upgrades or Retrofits – Upgrades can include actions ranging from replacing old inefficient appliances with new [[Energy Star]] appliances, adding [[Building insulation|insulation]], or replacing major systems like [[heating]] equipment or the [[roof]].
The energy improvement recommendations are drawn from the National Residential Energy Efficiency Measures Database.
== Awards & Recognition == Each year, the [[R&D 100 Awards]] recognize the year's 100 most significant, innovative, newly introduced research and development advances. The awards are recognized in industry, government, and academia as proof that a product is one of the most [[innovative]] ideas of the year, nationally and internationally. Home Energy Saver and [[Hohm]] received an [[R&D 100 Award]] in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|title=Meet the R&D 100 Winners for 2010|url=http://www.rdmag.com/Awards/RD-100-Awards/2010/07/R-D-100-2010-Winners-Overview/|publisher=R&D Magazine|accessdate=7 July 2010}}</ref>
Home Energy Saver received the [[U.S. Department of Energy]]'s "Energy 100" award as one of the best 100 scientific and technological accomplishments over DOE's 23-year lifetime.<ref>{{cite web|title=Department of Energy Honors Most Notable Scientific and Technological Accomplishments |url=http://www.science.energy.gov/News_Information/News_Room/2001/Most%20Notable%20Scientific.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100528130412/http://science.energy.gov/News_Information/News_Room/2001/Most%20Notable%20Scientific.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=28 May 2010 |publisher=U.S. Department of Energy |accessdate=8 January 2001 }}</ref> The discoveries were chosen based on their impact in saving consumers money and improving quality of life.
PC Magazine recognized Home Energy Saver in 2004 as one of the "Top 100 Undiscovered Websites.<ref>{{cite news|title=2004 100 Top Websites You Didn't Know You Couldn't Live Without|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2312019,00.asp|publisher=PC Magazine|accessdate=20 April 2004|date=20 April 2004}}</ref>
MSN-Money rates Home Energy Saver among the "Best Sites for Free Government Help" including it in the list of "The 100 most Useful Sites on the Internet.<ref>{{cite web|last=Pulliam Weston|first=Liz|title=The 100 most useful sites on the Internet|url=http://articles.moneycentral.msn.com/SavingandDebt/FindDealsOnline/weston-the-100-most-useful-sites-on-the-Internet.aspx|publisher=MSN|accessdate=2010}}</ref>
== Licensing == Organizations who want to provide their customers tools to predict home energy consumption can license the Home Energy Saver [[Application Programming Interfaces]] (APIs).
[[Microsoft]], the first organization to license the Home Energy Saver, uses it to drive Microsoft [[Hohm]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Katie|first=Fehrenbacher|title=Microsoft Reveals Its Energy Management Tool: Hohm|url=http://gigaom.com/cleantech/microsoft-reveals-its-energy-managent-tool-hohm/|publisher=GIGAom|accessdate=24 June 2009}}</ref>

'''Hybrid models of forest production''', sometimes abbreviated to ''hybrid models'', combine [[growth and yield modelling]] with physiological modelling.<ref>[[Euan Mason|Mason, E.G.]], Rose, R.W. and L.S. Rosner. 2008. Time vs light: A potentially usable light sum hybrid model to represent the juvenile growth of Douglas-fir subject to varying levels of competition, [[Canadian Journal of Forest Research]] 37, 795-605</ref><ref> Landsberg, J.J., and Waring, R.H. 1997. A generalised model of forest productivity using simplified concepts of radiation-use efficiency, carbon balance and partitioning. {{Infobox Organization |name = Integrated Operations in the High North |image = IOHN logo small.gif |size = 200 |alt = Logo for Integrated Operations in the High North. |caption = Logo for Integrated Operations in the High North. |abbreviation = IOHN or IO High North |formation = 2008-05-06 |status = Project at [[Det Norske Veritas|Det Norske Veritas (DNV)]] |purpose = Designing, implementing and testing a Digital Platform for the next generation of [[Integrated Operations]] |location = Bærum, Norway |region_served = Worldwide |membership = 22 |language = English |leader_title = Project Manager |leader_name = [http://www.linkedin.com/in/fredericverhelst Frédéric Verhelst] |main_organ = Steering Committee |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = }} '''Integrated Operations in the High North''' ('''IOHN''', '''IO High North or IO in the High North''') is a unique collaboration project that during a four-year period starting May 2008 is working on designing, implementing and testing a Digital Platform for what in the [[Upstream (oil industry)|Upstream Oil and Gas Industry]] is called the next or second generation of [[Integrated Operations]]. {{cite web |url=http://www.olf.no/getfile.php/zKonvertert/www.olf.no/Rapporter/Dokumenter/070919%20IO%20and%20Ontology%20-%20Brosjyre.pdf |title=Integrated Operations and the Oil and Gas Ontology |author=The [[Norwegian Oil Industry Association]] (OLF) and POSC Caesar Association (PCA) |accessdate=2009-05-06 |date=2007-09-19 }} The work on the Digital platform is focussed on capture, transfer and integration of [[Real-time data]] from the remote production installations to the decision makers. A risk evaluation across the whole chain is also included. The platform is based on [[open standards]] and enables a higher degree of [[interoperability]]. Requirements for the digital platform come from use cases defined within the [[Oil_and_gas_well_drilling#Drilling|Drilling]] and [[Oil_and_gas_well_drilling#Completion|Completion]], Reservoir and Production and Operations and Maintenance domains. The platform will subsequently be demonstrated through pilots within these three domains. {{cite web |url=http://trac.posccaesar.org/wiki/IOHN |title=Short introduction to the Integrated Operations in the High North (IOHN) project |author=Integrated Operations in the High North (IOHN) |accessdate=2009-05-07 }} This new platform is considered an important enabler for safe and sustainable operations in remote, vulnerable and hazardous areas such as the [[Arctic|High North]], {{cite web |url=http://www.olf.no/news/norway-takes-a-leading-role-in-next-generation-integrated-operations-article18586-291.html |title=Norway takes a leading role in next generation Integrated Operations |author=The [[Norwegian Oil Industry Association]] (OLF) |accessdate=2009-05-07 |date=2008-08-26 }} {{cite web |url=http://www.rigzone.com/news/article.asp?a_id=65883 |title=Norway Takes Reign to Provide Next Generation Integrated Operations |author=Rigzone E&P News |accessdate=2009-05-08 |date=2008-08-26 }} {{cite web |url=http://www.digitalenergyjournal.com/displaynews.php?NewsID=758&PHPSESSID=9hhp6qe4qqpi7qnbgffgqhv1h7 |title=Norway developing next generation Integrated Operations |author=Digital Energy Journal |accessdate=2009-05-08 |date=2008-08-27 }} {{cite web |url=http://www.epmag.com/Magazine/2008/12/item24047.php |title=Offshore R&D pushes the limits |author=E&P Magazine |accessdate=2009-05-08 |date=2008-12-02 }} but the technology is clearly also applicable in more general applications. The IOHN project consortium consists of 23 participants, {{cite web |url=http://www.posccaesar.org/wiki/IOHN/participants |title=List of participating companies in the IOHN project |author=[[IOHN]] |accessdate=2010-03-10 |date=2010-03-10 }} including operators, service providers, software vendors, technology providers, research institutions and universities. In addition, the [[Norwegian Defence Force]] is working with the project to resolve common infrastructural and [[interoperability]] challenges. The project is managed by [[DNV|Det Norske Veritas (DNV)]]. {{cite web |url=http://www.dnv.com/news_events/news/2008/dnvleadsintegratedoperationsdevelopment.asp |title=DNV leads Integrated Operations development |author=[[Det Norske Veritas]] (DNV) |accessdate=2009-05-07 |date=2008-08-26 }} Nils Sandsmark was the project manager during the initiation and start-up phase. Frédéric Verhelst took over as project manager from the beginning of 2009. {{cite web |url=http://www.linkedin.com/in/fredericverhelst |title=Profile of Frédéric Verhelst |author=[[LinkedIn]] |accessdate=2009-09-28 }} Financing comes from the participants and the [[Research Council of Norway]] (RCN) for parts of the project (GOICT {{cite web |url=http://www.forskningsradet.no/servlet/Satellite?c=Prosjekt&cid=1207296035860&pagename=verdikt/Hovedsidemal&p=1226993814962 |title=Dependable ICT for the Energy Sector (GOICT, RCN proj.no. 183235, VERDIKT-programme) |author=The [[Research Council of Norway]] (RCN) |accessdate=2009-05-07 }} and AutoConRig {{cite web |url=http://www.forskningsradet.no/servlet/Satellite?c=Prosjekt&cid=1198060412649&pagename=ForskningsradetNorsk/Hovedsidemal&p=1181730334233 |title=Semi-autonomous control system for unmanned drilling rigs (AutoConRig, RCN proj.no. 187473, PETROMAKS-programme) |author=The [[Research Council of Norway]] (RCN) |accessdate=2009-05-07 }} {{cite web |url=http://www.posccaesar.org/wiki/IOHN/AutoConRig |title=RCN/NFR project "AutoConRig" |author=Jens Ornæs (NOV) |accessdate=2009-07-02 }}). == Participants == The consortium consists of the following 22 participants (in alphabetical order):
{| class="wikitable" |- | [[ABB Group|ABB]] | [http://www.abelia.no Abelia] | [[Baker Hughes]] | [[Cisco]] | [http://www.computas.no Computas] |- | [[Det Norske Veritas]] | [[Eni|ENI]] | [http://www.epsis.no Epsis] | [[FMC Technologies]] | [http://www.fsi.no FSI] |- | [http://www.ntnu.no/iocenter IO Center] | [http://www.iris.no IRIS] | [[National Oilwell Varco]] | [[Norwegian University of Science and Technology|NTNU]] | [http://www.olf.no OLF] |- | [[POSC Caesar Association]] | [http://www.ptil.no Petroleum Safety Authority Norway] | [[Siemens]] | [[Statoil]] | [[Norwegian Defence]] |- | [[University of Oslo]] | [[University of Stavanger]] |} == See also == * [[Integrated Operations]] * [[Semantic Web]] * [[ISO 15926]] aka [[Oil and Gas Ontology]], an enabler for the next or second generation of [[Integrated Operations]] by integrating data across disciplines and business domains. * [[Petroleum exploration in the Arctic]] * [[POSC Caesar Association]], the custodian of [[ISO 15926]], the [[Oil and Gas Ontology]]. == References == {{reflist|2}} == External links == * [http://www.IOHN.org/ Integrated Operations in the High North] website * [[W3C]] workshop on [http://www.w3.org/2008/12/ogws-report.html Semantic Web in Oil and Gas industry], Houston, December 9–10, 2008. [http://www.w3.org/2008/12/ogws-report#papers Position papers] from several participants in IOHN. * [http://www.posccaesar.org/wiki/PCA/SemanticDays2009/AboutSemanticDays Semantic Days 2009] conference, Stavanger, May 18–20, 2009. One [http://www.posccaesar.org/wiki/PCA/SemanticDays2009#Session6:SemantictechnologyforIOGeneration2 session] is devoted to IOHN. * [http://www.ioconf.no/2009/ IO 09 Science and Practice] conference, Trondheim, September 29–30, 2009. One [http://ioconf.no/2009/parallel6 session] is devoted to IOHN. * [http://www.oilit.com/2journal/2article/1003_16.htm#IOHN Integrated Operations in the High North—mid term report], ''Oil IT Journal'', March 2010. {{DEFAULTSORT:Integrated Operations In The High North}} [[Category:Petroleum organizations]] [[Category:Petroleum engineering]] [[Category:Semantic Web]] [[Category:Knowledge engineering]] [[Category:Information science]] [[Category:Ontology (information science)]] [[Category:Knowledge representation]]

[[File:Wood Carver Kim Bong.JPG|thumb|A woodcarver plies his trade at a Kim Bồng woodworking studio.]] '''Kim Bồng woodworking village''' ({{lang-vi|Làng mộc Kim Bồng}}) is a village located in Cẩm Kim commune, [[Hội An]], [[Quảng Nam Province]], most notable for its [[carpentry]] (including [[cabinet making]] and [[shipbuilding]]) and traditional [[woodworking]] products. Established in the 15th century, it reached its peak in the 18th century, during which time village craftsmen contributed their skills in woodworking to many different projects, including the [[Imperial City, Huế|Imperial capital]] in [[Huế]].<ref name="vnnet-june09" /> Using their shipbuilding skills, they supplied ships and ''ghe bầu'' (large boats used for sailing) for the activities of the busy commercial port of Hội An.<ref name="vnnet-june09" />
To deal with a marked decline of interest in the woodworking profession during the 20th century, the village successfully offered training and other incentives to young apprentices,<ref name="vnnet-june09" /> resulting in an increase to over 200 woodworkers and 18 different woodcarving companies as of 2008.<ref name="unesco-impact" /> Additionally, a successful community-based tourism project in Kim Bồng has allowed greater tourism revenue for the village; the venture's success has been suggested as a pattern for future [[sustainable tourism]] projects throughout [[Southeast Asia]].<ref name="eprp06" />
The village's name comes from the Vietnamese ''kim'' (yellow) and ''bồng'' (floating), supposedly after the [[jackfruit]] wood that sometimes floats on the [[Thu Bồn River]].
== History == Kim Bồng was settled in the 15th century, supposedly by four soldiers from the army of Emperor [[Lê Lợi]], who founded the Later [[Lê Dynasty]]. According to traditional stories, these four soldiers were adept at [[woodworking]], and went on to establish the village's four most notable craft families (Huynh, Nguyen, Phan, and Truong), many of whose members carry on that trade to the present day. As the neighbouring town of [[Hội An]] developed during the late 16th and early 17th centuries, Kim Bồng's [[carpentry|carpenters]] and woodworkers became more widely known; in the 17th century, local carpenters were supposedly commissioned to build a warship for the Spanish navy.<ref name="vnnet-june09" /> Craftsmen from Kim Bồng also produced most of the detail work on the buildings of the former Imperial capital in [[Huế]], and, more recently, on Vietnamese revolutionary leader [[Ho Chi Minh]]'s tomb.<ref name="vnnet-june09">{{cite news|url=http://english.vietnamnet.vn/lifestyle/2009/06/850646/|title=Kim Bong village carves itself into history|date=2009-06-01|publisher=VietnamNet|accessdate=2010-07-05|archiveurl=http://www.lookatvietnam.com/2009/06/kim-bong-village-carves-itself-into-history.html|archivedate=2010-10-15}} {{Unreliable source?|date=July 2010}}</ref>
In the present day, Kim Bồng craftsmen are often involved in restoration projects. For example, since the old town of Hội An was designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1999, many of the village's artisans have found work restoring historic buildings, some of which have remained otherwise untouched for hundreds of years. Local craftsmen have also worked on restoration projects in nearby [[Da Nang]], and in [[Quảng Ninh Province]].<ref name="vnnet-june09" />
==Economy== [[File:Three Heads in Kim Bong.JPG|thumb|190px|Kim Bồng wood carvings.]] As its popular appellation suggests, the economy of Kim Bồng has long been dominated by [[carpentry]] (including [[cabinetmaking]] and [[shipbuilding]]) and [[woodworking]]. Kim Bồng woodwork is featured on unique columns, rafters and furniture found throughout the greater [[Hội An]] area and [[Quảng Nam Province]];<ref name="unesco-impact">{{cite web|url=http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0018/001826/182646e.pdf|title=Cultural Tourism and Heritage Management in the World Heritage Site of the Ancient Town of Hoi An, Viet Nam|work=IMPACT: The Effects of Tourism on Culture and the Environment in Asia and the Pacific|publisher=UNESCO Bangkok|year=2008|accessdate=2010-07-05}}</ref> local craftsmen have also been employed in many high-profile projects in Vietnam, including detail work on the buildings of the former [[Imperial City, Huế|Imperial capital]] in [[Huế]], and on [[Vietnam]]ese [[revolutionary]] leader [[Ho Chi Minh]]'s tomb.
In more recent years, woodworking as a profession fell out of favour with young people, mainly due to poor returns: the average income of a woodworker in Kim Bồng is about [[Vietnamese đồng|VND]] 1.5 million (US$85) per month. By the 1990s, few master carvers remained in the village. To help promote the profession, Cẩm Kim commune created a program allowing young people to receive free training in carpentry and woodworking, along with providing a monthly stipend of VND 150,000 ($8) and tools of the trade.<ref name="vnnet-june09" /> Training courses are provided by master carver Huynh Ri, whose family includes 12 generations of woodcarvers. Several other local woodworking studios also provide on-the-job training to apprentice woodcarvers. These training programs have resulted in an increase in skilled woodworkers: the village numbered over 200 workers and 18 different woodcarving companies as of 2008. These results were lauded by UNESCO as "keeping the traditional skills and intangible heritage of the town of Hoi An and its surrounding villages alive".<ref name="unesco-impact" />
Tourism is a more recent contributor to the local economy, beginning in 2002, when the Vietnam National Administration of Tourism (VNAT) led a community-based tourism project in Kim Bồng, together with [[UNESCO]] and the [[United Nations Conference on Trade and Development]]/[[World Trade Organization]]'s Export-led Poverty Reduction Programme (EPRP). The village was selected as a promising location for the project because of its proximity to Hội An (already a major tourist destination), which provided an existing tourist base, and its existing craft sector. A dual pedestrian-[[segregated cycle facilities|bicycle trail]] was established to lead visitors through the village to see the local woodworking shops, where they are able to observe craftsmen working and purchase their products. Concurrent with the development of infrastructure, a tourism service [[cooperative]] was established, as well as a skills training program for members and a marketing program which resulted in market linkages with several major hotels and tour operators operating in Hội An. Local and provincial tourism authorities have also incorporated the village into festivals and promotional campaigns. The success of the venture has led it to be considered a model case on which future [[sustainable tourism]] projects throughout Southeast Asia can be patterned.<ref name="eprp06">{{cite web|url=http://www.intracen.org/wedf/ef2006/global-debate/Case-Studies/Vietnam.pdf|title=Poverty Reduction Through Community-Based Tourism in Viet Nam: A Case Study|author=Export-led Poverty Reduction Programme (UNCTAD/WTO)|date=October 2006|accessdate=2010-07-05}}</ref>
==See also== *[[List of Vietnamese handicraft villages]]
